metadata.notes: First sermon in a series on Romans; delivered July 2, 1978. Focuses heavily on the doctrine of Sin and Wrath.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher adopts the CP role to dismantle the listener's defenses. The language of 'guilty,' 'miserable offenders,' and 'deserving of death' is a classic CP maneuver to induce shame and compliance.
quotes: There is not one of us here that is not guilty
You are storing up wrath for yourself
Wretched human beings that we are!

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The NP appears primarily through the 'we' pronoun, positioning the preacher as a fellow sufferer in a 'sinking lifeboat,' though this care is secondary to the CP's judgment.
quotes: as sisters and brothers in the same sinking lifeboat
It will help us on our way to the finest possible understanding

adult.analysis: The preacher uses a strong Adult ego state to process historical data (Luther, Niebuhr, Menninger) and literary analysis (Golding). The listener is invited to 'listen to Paul's discussion' and 'empty our minds,' which are Adult-to-Adult invitations.
quotes: Let us give Paul the benefit of the doubt here.
In order to understand what this is all about, we have to empty our minds of all the ideas that we were raised with

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly aims to move the listener into the Adapted Child (AC) position—specifically the 'Guilty Child' who confesses and submits to the Parent's law.
quotes: Let us not flinch from the truth about ourselves.
summon every one of us here to realize and to confess

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a brief moment of FC in the intro ('I want to keep my job'), but it is quickly suppressed by the gravity of the 'Wrath' theme.
quotes: I thought about calling it 'The Wrath of God,' but... I want to keep my job.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher uses Adult data (theology/literature) to establish authority, then shifts to a Parent-Child transaction to demand confession and repentance.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The 'Social' level is an Adult study of Romans; the 'Psychological' level is a Parent inducing guilt in the Child to ensure submission to the church's structure.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the promise of 'Good News' that is withheld. The preacher intentionally leaves the listener in a state of 'Wretchedness' without the resolution of grace, creating a psychological cliffhanger.

detected_games.name: NIGYSOB (Now I've Got You, You Son of a Bitch)

formula_g_analysis.con: Invites the listener to judge 'those people' (the ungodly/Gentiles).
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's sense of moral superiority or 'in-group' status.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher turns the text: 'Therefore, you have no excuse... you do them yourself.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener is trapped in guilt; the preacher maintains the 'I'm OK, You're Not OK' position.

evidence_quotes: Paul’s readers will have been nodding their heads in agreement... But Paul turns the argument around. Instead of saying they, he suddenly starts saying you.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch

formula_g_analysis.con: Promising a sermon on 'Good News' and 'Grace'.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for relief and spiritual comfort.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Explicitly refusing to 'turn the corner' to grace, leaving the listener in the 'Wrath'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels 'miserable' (as stated in the final prayer), ensuring they return for the next 'fix' of the series.

evidence_quotes: This sermon is going to come to an end in a minute. We are not going to turn the corner today.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low; the preacher explicitly refuses to rescue the listener in this installment.
preacher_roles.persecutor: High; the preacher uses the 'Wrath of God' as a tool to convict and blame the listener.
preacher_roles.victim: Low; though the preacher identifies as a 'sinner,' it is a position of strength used to trap others.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim (of Sin, of the Law, and of the Preacher's psychological trap).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: No. The preacher closes the exit by stating 'We are not going to turn the corner today,' effectively locking the congregation in the 'Wretched' position.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: While intellectually stimulating and homiletically 'clever,' the sermon is psychologically taxing. It utilizes a sophisticated 'NIGYSOB' game to dismantle the listener's ego. By intentionally withholding the 'Rescuer' role (the Gospel) until a future date, the preacher creates an unhealthy dependency and leaves the congregation in a state of 'Adapted Child' guilt. The use of the General Confession as a 'payoff' solidifies the 'I'm Not OK' position of the listener.
strengths: High Adult ego engagement through literary and historical references.
Effective dismantling of 'Ain't It Awful' (judging others) by turning the mirror on the self.
areas_for_improvement: The intentional withholding of resolution (Grace) is a manipulative 'cliffhanger' technique.
The heavy reliance on Critical Parent language ('guilty,' 'miserable') can trigger trauma rather than transformation.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: To move toward Adult-Adult communication, offer the 'solution' (Grace) alongside the 'problem' (Sin) in the same transaction. Avoid 'trapping' the listener; instead, present the reality of sin as a data point for Adult reflection rather than a Parent's stick for shaming.
